## <span aria-hidden="true">ğŸ§­</span> Origins â€” From Observers to Databases

The story begins in the late 19th century.\
Long before satellites and sensors, weather was measured by hand â€” **Cooperative Observer Program (COOP)** volunteers using thermometers and rain gauges.\
In 1890, the U.S. Weather Bureau (now the **National Weather Service**) organized these thousands of observers to provide a daily national picture.

By the 1930s, these logs were centralized under what became the **National Climatic Data Center (NCDC)** â€” and eventually **NOAAâ€™s National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI)**.\
Their mission was simple but monumental: **preserve the planetâ€™s weather memory**.

Today, the result is the **Global Historical Climatology Network â€“ Daily (GHCN-Daily)**, containing billions of daily records from over 100,000 land-based stations across 180 countries.

## <span aria-hidden="true">ğŸ§®</span> Example Exploration

Imagine this:\
You download 50 years of daily maximum temperatures for your city and plot how many summer days exceeded 95 Â°F each year.\
Youâ€™d likely see the creeping signature of a warming world.

Or perhaps you cross-match rainfall with flight delays, crop yields, or local power consumption.\
Suddenly, weather becomes *behavioral data* â€” showing how the sky shapes our choices below.

``` r
# Example R snippet for NOAA Daily Summaries
library(rnoaa)
library(dplyr)

# Pull last 30 years of daily summaries for a station
ghcnd_stations() |> 
  filter(grepl("LITTLE ROCK", name)) |> 
  slice_head(n = 1) |> 
  pull(id) -> station_id

data <- meteo_pull_monitors(station_id, date_min = "1995-01-01", var = c("TMAX", "TMIN", "PRCP"))

data |> 
  mutate(year = lubridate::year(date)) |>
  group_by(year) |>
  summarise(hot_days = sum(TMAX > 35, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  ggplot(aes(year, hot_days)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Number of Hot Days (TMAX > 35Â°C) per Year",
       y = "Count", x = "Year")
```

This small snippet turns daily data into an evolving climate portrait.
